## R statistical programming language:
R <http://www.r-project.org/> is well worth learning if you are interested in Big Data and new communication through data

- free, and available for all platforms
- versatility - swiss army knife
- decent documentation; great support

---

## Some packages I have used, for:

- Big Data analysis - scholar
- software integration - RNetLogo
- combining visual and statistical analysis - igraph
- visualising multidimensional data - ggplot2
- interactive web applications - shiny
- other dynamic web outputs
    + presentations - slidify
    + reports - knitr

---

## examples
- Shiny see <https://richarit.shinyapps.io/shiny-simex/>
- Scholar
```{r, echo=FALSE}
library(scholar)
library(ggplot2)
library(zoo)
SEI.ids <- c("oqRgrAIAAAAJ&hl", "GXuL9-8AAAAJ&hl", "Cad6mKIAAAAJ&hl", "a0W9s1AAAAAJ&hl", "WDLy64sAAAAJ&hl", "gLI6MR0AAAAJ&hl","yV7mkpoAAAAJ&hl")
cit.histories <- lapply(SEI.ids, get_citation_history)

cit.zoo <- lapply(cit.histories, function(x) zoo(x,x$year))
cites.zoo <-sapply(cit.zoo, function(x) subset(x, select=cites))
df.cites.zoo <- do.call(merge,  cites.zoo)
names(df.cites.zoo) <- SEI.ids

profiles <- sapply(SEI.ids, get_profile)
nscholars <- ncol(profiles)
mfrow.cols <- 3
mfrow.rows <- floor(nscholars /mfrow.cols)

opar <- par(las = 1, mar = c(3, 3, 2, 2),las=1, cex.axis = 0.8, mfrow=c(mfrow.rows,mfrow.cols))
for (x in c(1:prod(mfrow.rows,mfrow.cols))) {
  sch <- SEI.ids [x]
  history <- df.cites.zoo[,x]
  plot(history, xlab = NA, ylab = NA)#, plot.type = "single", col = eight.cols, ylim=c(0,10), axes=FALSE, xlab = NA, ylab = NA, lty=3)#, xlab="Tick",ylab="Number of individuals")
  
  #ggplot(data=history, aes(x=year, y=cites)) # + geom_line(aes(linetype=name)) + theme_bw()
}
```
